articles.headline: Tentative Deal Reached to Preserve Cut in Payroll Tax
articles.snippet: Republicans and Democrats both claimed a measure of victory as the tax reduction was extended without spending cuts to pay for it.
articles.abstract: Republicans and Democrats both claimed a measure of victory as the tax reduction was extended without spending cuts to pay for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of a House-Senate committee charged with writing a measure to extend a payroll tax reduction and provide added unemployment benefits reached a tentative agreement Tuesday evening, with Republicans and Democrats claiming a degree of political victory in a fight with significant election-year implications.

articles.headline: Portugal’s Debt Efforts May Be Warning for Greece
articles.snippet: Despite meeting terms for bailout money, Portugal is going deeper into debt because its economy is shrinking.
articles.abstract: Despite meeting terms for bailout money, Portugal is going deeper into debt because its economy is shrinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON — As debt-plagued Greece struggles to meet Europe’s strict terms for receiving its next round of bailout money, the lesson of Portugal might bear watching.

articles.headline: Greece Expected to Offer Debt Holders a Deal Soon
articles.snippet: Some bondholders, facing a loss of nearly 70 percent, may prefer to continue the battle in court.
articles.abstract: Some bondholders, facing a loss of nearly 70 percent, may prefer to continue the battle in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Greek government presents its debt relief proposal to bondholders in the next week, it could lead to one of the largest debt restructurings in history.

articles.headline: Economic Growth Gives Lift to Obama in NYT/CBS Poll
articles.snippet: President Obama’s approval rating reached the 50 percent mark, while Republican voters expressed a desire for more alternatives in their race, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s approval rating reached the 50 percent mark, while Republican voters expressed a desire for more alternatives in their race, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s political standing is rising along with voters’ optimism that the economy is getting better, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, a shift that coincides with continued Republican disquiet over the field of candidates seeking to replace him.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Allison Kopicki

articles.headline: Hip Implant U.S. Rejected Was Sold Overseas
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson recalled the hip device, and a similar one sold in the United States, in 2010 after data showed a disturbingly high failure rate.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson recalled the hip device, and a similar one sold in the United States, in 2010 after data showed a disturbingly high failure rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The health care products giant Johnson & Johnson continued to market an artificial hip in Europe and elsewhere overseas after the Food and Drug Administration rejected its sale in the United States based on a review of company safety studies.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Bars the Use of Airwaves for a Broadband Plan
articles.snippet: The commission reversed the conditional approval for a network that would use frequencies once reserved for satellite-telephone transmissions.
articles.abstract: The commission reversed the conditional approval for a network that would use frequencies once reserved for satellite-telephone transmissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A proposed wireless broadband network that would provide voice and Internet service using airwaves once reserved for satellite-telephone transmissions should be shelved because it interferes with GPS technology, the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday.

articles.headline: 19 Years and £1 Million Later, a Past Catches Up
articles.snippet: Edward Maher, a suspect in a million-pound robbery in England in 1993, was arrested last week in a mostly rural corner of southwest Missouri.
articles.abstract: Edward Maher, a suspect in a million-pound robbery in England in 1993, was arrested last week in a mostly rural corner of southwest Missouri.
articles.lead_paragraph: OZARK, Mo. — As she listened to the outlandish story pour out, slightly slurred, from her new husband’s mouth, Jessica King dismissed the tale of his family’s two-decade run from the law as the product of an overactive imagination and too many drinks.

articles.headline: Blaze at Prison Underscores Broad Security Problems in Honduras
articles.snippet: In one of the worst prison fires in recent years in Latin America, with more than 300 dead, most of the victims choked to death in their cells awaiting a rescue that never came.
articles.abstract: In one of the worst prison fires in recent years in Latin America, with more than 300 dead, most of the victims choked to death in their cells awaiting a rescue that never came.
articles.lead_paragraph: COMAYAGUA, Honduras — The bodies of the inmates, shirtless and blackened by soot, lay on the ground in neat rows, belying the chaos from which they emerged.
articles.byline: By Javier C. Hernández and Randal C. Archibold
